elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
1. INT. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM
FX: TARDIS ENGINES IN TORMENT; TUMBLING THROUGH THE SKIES ABOVE
MANCHESTER, CAREERING THROUGH THE CENTURIES. SCREECHING,
WAILING, AS IF CHOKED WITH HORRIBLE POLLUTION.
What’s happening to the TARDIS?
We’re hurtling through the skies somewhere above Manchester.
Through the skies?!
The navigational systems are malfunctioning due to travelling backwards through decades of carboniferous emissions.
Yes, it appears the old girl doesn’t much care for the Industrial Revolution.
So you’re saying we got lost in the smog?!
Worse than that! We’re flying blind! Brace yourselves!
What, we’re going to crash?
Can’t you dematerialise, Doctor?
Too late! Positions...!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 3
2. EXT. GROUNDS OF HURLEY HALL, CHEADLE HULME. NIGHT.
FX: ALMIGHTY CRASH - THE TARDIS LANDS HEAVILY ON TREES IN THE
GROUNDS OF HURLEY HALL, A LITTLE WAY AWAY. SMASHING AND SPLINTERING. COMES TO STOP. CROSSFADE TO:
(RUNNING UP) Cathy! Cathy!
Hurry with the lamp, William. It’s in the trees, whatever it Siz
Have a care, Cathy. That noise... it was something hellish. It wasn’t of this earth!
And you a man of industry and science? Master William, you’re as credulous as any of us servants.
(DISTANT, APPROACHING) William! William, where are you?
Over here, Father.
(HURRYING OVER) What the devil’s going on out here? It sounded like a hundred barrels of gunpowder going off!
There’s something in the trees.
Are you sure, girl...?
FX: DISTANT CRACKLING UNDERGROWTH FROM THE TREELINE — TARDIS
APPROACHING.
Sssh! Listen!
Don’t you shush your master!
Can’t you hear? There are voices...!
FX: CROSS TO THE TARDIS CREW’S POV, COMING THROUGH TREES.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 4
This way! I can hear voices.
And lights! Doctor, there are lights. There’s a building of some kind...
A mansion, by the looks of it.
(STRUGGLING THROUGH BRANCHES) Hold on, I’m a bit caught up in these branches... (FREE) Ah! Yes, it is rather a big house, isn’t it?
(DISTANT) Hello? Who are you?
(DISTANT) Where the devil did you come from? What was that horrific hullaballoo?
They don’t look very friendly.
Well, we shall just have to tread carefully — (STUMBLES) Argh!
Doctor? Are you alright?
Perfectly, I — (WINCES) Ow! I seem to have twisted my ankle.
So much for treading carefully.
(CLOSER NOW) Who the devil are you people?
Hello! I’m the Doctor. I’m terribly sorry to have ended up
dropping in on you like this, in the middle of the night...
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 5
3. INT. DRAWING ROOM. NIGHT
FX: HURRYING FOOTSTEPS LEADING TRAVELLERS INTO DRAWING ROOM,
TICKING GRANDFATHER CLOCK.
Nice place you’ve got here!
FX: DOORS TO DRAWING-ROOM OPENED.
Yes, come on, come on. I’d rather hear you people explain yourselves in the drawing room, rather than stand around outside.
You’re very kind. (WINCES AGAIN)
FX: FOLLOW THEM INTO DRAWING ROOM.
Good God — what are you wearing, all three of you?!
Clothes?
Never mind, sit down. Cathy? Fellow here looks in need of something restorative.
I’1l get Cook to warm some milk.
Milk, by hang! Brandy’s what’s required here.
(SITTING) Really, you mustn’t go to any bothevr...
(CALLING) Dodson! — Dammit, where is that butler? (CALLING) We need drink here! On the double!
Isn’t that the drinks cabinet just over there?
Shush, Tegan.
Dodson!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 6
Father, you’ll be waking up mother. She needs her rest...
I told her not to leave her room, until I knew what’s going on. (TO DOCTOR) And I’m still none the wiser, sir!
Ah, yes. Well, that was our fault. My fault, really. It was my ship.
Ship?
We’re a long way from the sea!
This will take some explaining.
And we will sit here until you have explained to my satisfaction how and why you’ve managed to bring down the finest stand of oaks in all of Cheadle Hulme.
Father, calm down. They seem like reasonable people...
Causing explosions in the night? Reasonable? My heart nearly leapt out of my chest! I thought revolution had come! — Now you,
sir, will explain what you mean about a ‘ship’!
(DEEP BREATH) Well...
In the morning, perhaps? — Father?
Very well, in the morning. But I’1ll have my answers then, sir — you see that I don’t!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 7
4: INT. CATHY’S HOME. EARLY MORNING.
FX: MUSICAL CUE SUGGESTING DAWN. COCK CROWING OUTSIDE. RATTLE
OF DOOR AS CATHY LETS HERSELF INTO LOWLY DWELLING BELONGING TO
FATHER. CRACKLING FIRE.
Cathy?! — Where have you been, girl? You should have been back hours ago.
Shush, father. Everything’s fine. Here, you’ve let the fire burn down...
FX: SHE STOKES THE FIRE, CLANGS POTS.
The child was up through the night. He won’t settle unless you’re here...
There was a something strange going on. I was needed.
(MORE HEATED) I need you here. So does your... little brother.
Hush. You’1ll wake hin...
Bargain was, you’d be here to do all the household tasks, same as your mother used to. Then I can keep working, and doing early starts.
I know that, father. I’m here, aren’t I?
The pittance you make at Hurley Hall won’t keep us, will it? I’ve got to work. Even sick as I am.
Things will get easier...
They will, will they? And when’s that?
You’11l see. Things have to get better.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 8
I don’t see how. And I don’t see your fancy friends changing anything, either. Not any time soon.
(LAUGHING) What fancy friends have I got?
You know who I mean. That lot you fell in with. Speechifiers. Talkers.
There’s nothing wrong with talking.
FX: FIDDLING WITH TEA THINGS, KETTLE WHISTLING ON HOB.
Rabble-rousing. That’s what it is. And you won’t be allowed to get away with it.
Come on, Dad. Get this tea. Have you time for porridge?
Tend to yourself. And prepare the boy’s breakfast. He’1ll hear your voice and want to be up. I have to go. But tell me — why were you out all night?

Oh! They had an emergency up at the Hall. It was the oddest thing... these people, strangers, turning up out of nowhere. Like no-one else you’ve ever seen. They claim they just fell out of the sky. In some kind of box.
I don’t like the sound of that. What were you needed for?
I had to see to them. Get them rooms sorted out. The Hurleys of Cheadle pride themselves on their hospitality, you know...
Oh yes, the big man in his high castle. I still don’t like the sound of all this. Folk dropping out of the sky...
Quite nice folk, as it turns out. They were very friendly to me.
You take far too much interest in life outside this house. You've got duties here.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 9
This is about the march tomorrow, isn’t it? You don’t want me to go.
No, I don’t. You or the child.
But it’ll be the most important thing that’s ever happened to me.
The most important things are here.
It’s only one day!
I forbid it. Do you hear me, Cathy? You’re not going anywhere!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 10
5. INT. HURLEY HALL — DOCTOR’S ROOM. DAY.
FX: KNOCKING ON DOCTOR’S BEDROOM DOOR; HE ANSWERS.
Ah, it’s you two. Good.
How’s your ankle this morning?
Sore.
FX: TEGAN AND NYSSA ENTER ROOM
Oh, your room is lovely, too. What a beautiful house this is...
Yeah, if you like that sort of thing. I can’t stand all those servants hanging around...
Do you know when and where we are, Doctor?
Not entirely. I must go back to the TARDIS and check her over at the first opportunity.
I hope she’s all right.
Tough as old boots. I hope. — Anyway, broadly speaking, we’re sometime in the early nineteenth century, somewhere south of Manchester.
Come on, you two. Whenever and wherever we are, I’m starving.
Someone was bashing a gong before.
Yes. It means, ‘Breakfast is served.’
More bowing and scraping. Still...
Why is it you don’t like the servants, Tegan?
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 11
I didn’t say I didn’t like them. I just don’t like to see people treated like slaves.
They seemed happy enough in their work.
They’ve got no choice!
Not the way the world is run at this point in time, no.
(LAUGHING) You can talk — you’re a posho, too!
I am not a ‘posho’.
Course you are, you’re a Time Lord. Nyssa’s told me all about Gallifrey, don’t you worry...
Nonetheless, we’re not here to change the world. We’1ll have a nice breakfast, then it’s back to the TARDIS.
We could carry you down on a litter, if you like?
Ssh.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 12
6. INT. HURLEY HALL — DINING ROOM. DAY.
FX: FADE UP GENTEEL CLATTER AND TINKLE OF BREAKFAST DISHES.
DOCTOR, TEGAN & NYSSA ENTER.
(GRANDLY) Ah, the good Doctor and his friends. Our esteemed guests!
Good morning, sir.
Hurley, please. We don’t stand on ceremony here. Actually, we do, my wife rather likes it. Come and sit, come and sit...
FX: SCRAPING OF CHAIRS, AS THEY SIT.
I’m ravenous.
This all looks wonderful...
That idle son of mine will be down soon. He seems to need more sleep than anyone else.
William? He seemed very nice.
He’s had everything on a plate, that boy. Just handed to him, like I never had.
You're a self-made man, I take it?
Give me a man who’s worked his way up in the world. Who knows how things tick. That’s what the country needs. A man who knows all the nuts and bolts.
You’ve done all right for yourself, yeah.
You're a very outspoken young miss.
She’s from abroad. Raised in the bush.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 13
Just hang on a moment...
Colonies, eh? Explains a lot. And your other niece, hm, Doctor? She looks like she could be an exotic princess of some kind.
I’m not actually a princess, but I am from somewhere more exotic than Cheadle Hulme.
FX: WILLIAM ENTERS IN A HURRY.
Good morning, father. And... er, everyone else.
Stirred yourself, have you?
I’ve been out with Dodson and the others, as it happens. We’ve been surveying the... ah, damage.
Have you, by gad? And what did you find?
Just a few lopped branches, really. It sounded worse that it is.
Well, hurrah for the trees.
And our, um, guests are speaking the truth.
In what sense, sir?
There is, in fact, a blue box amongst the oaks. Lying on its Side and utterly impregnable.
The Doctor’s TARDIS, yes.
(TO DOCTOR) A ship. You called it your ship, sir.
Yes. I did, didn’t I? Well, I can’t really explain too much about it...
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 14
It’s an invention, isn’t it? It’s something very clever. Very new.
How would you know that?
My dear, I am an engineer. An industrialist. I can smell something new when it drops in my lap. Something valuable.
I’m not sure it looks valuable exactly...
You must show it to us, Doctor. This ‘ship’ you arrived in. William — fetch men and tackle, so we can right the Doctor’s vessel.
Very good, father. (EXITS)
I don’t think that’s a good idea.
Do you not, sir? Well, I think it is. I’1ll have you know, I’ma magistrate. My word is law round here, as it happens.
The TARDIS would be of no interest to you.
You've accepted my hospitality in return for honest answers. So: we’ll finish our breakfast; then we’ll go and have a gander at this box of yours, hm?
FADE.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 15
7: EXT. HURLEY HALL — DRIVEWAY. DAY.
FX: FADE UP. CATHY HURRYING OVER GRAVEL TOWARDS HOUSE; SPOTS
WILLIAM.
William! Am I in trouble? I’m late...
Calm yourself, Cathy. Why are you so worked up?
It’s my dad. He had a right go at me about getting home so late last night.
He doesn’t like you working here, does he?
He doesn’t like anything I do.
I don’t suppose he’s going to be very pleased about this famous march of yours tomorrow...
You don’t take it serious either. I should never have told you about it.
I do take it seriously. I think you shouldn’t get involved.
I must. It’s about people’s livelihoods and about you lot... you tycoons and landowners and... and you just laugh about it...
I’m not laughing about your cause! I’m sure it’s all very laudable and important. It’s just you! My little pal. Cathy Roberts the kitchen maid.
Those days are gone, Master William. We live in different worlds. Life is more serious now.
Perhaps so. But what about those strangers though, eh? They seem rather colourful and out of the ordinary...!
You just like the look of the girls. — Look, I’d best get inside. Cook will have my guts for garters...
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 16
(IMPULSIVE) Cathy...
What is it?
I’m glad you’re back with us at Hurley Hall. When you went away last year.. down south to your cousin’s.. I thought we’d lost you forever.
I belong here. I’m not going any time soon.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 17
8. EXT. GROUNDS — NEAR THE TARDIS IN THE TREES. DAY.
FX: FADE UP SERVANTS HAULING BROKEN BRANCHES, TRYING TO FREE
TARDIS.
That’s it, you men... Careful, now! Don’t damage the precious box any further!
This is very kind of you.
It’s most exciting, Doctor. This flying machine you claim to have piloted into my garden... it’s nothing more than a miracle! Whoever imagined such a thing?
Well, it isn’t really a flying machine, you see...
CROSS TO — TEGAN AND NYSSA STANDING TO ONE SIDE:
I presume we’re going to run for it at some point...?
That depends what damage the TARDIS has suffered.
So, we might be stuck here a while?
At least it seems a civilized sort of era.
You think?
(OFF) Ah! I think I can get through now...
(OFF) Stand aside, men...
Doctor? Do you need us?
FX: OFF, CLATTERING TARDIS DOOR.
(OFF, COUGHING ON SMOKE FROM INSIDE TARDIS) Ah...!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 18
Did you see that? There’s smoke coming out of the door!
(OFF, CALLING TO DOCTOR) Shall I instruct my men to fetch buckets?
(OFF, CALLING BACK) No, there’s no fire... but there seems to be quite a lot of damage...
FX: OFF, TARDIS DOOR SHUTS.
Rabbits. We’re going to get stuck here, and I’1l end up becoming my own great-great-grandmother, won’t I?
The chances of that happening are remarkably slim.
(OFF, CALLING TO DOCTOR) Don’t lock yourself away in your strange box, Doctor...!
NYSSA3: I don’t like that man much.
He seems a bit of a bully. But his son’s all right.
(ARCH) Do you think so, Tegan?
FX: TARDIS DOORS OPENS, AND A COUGHING DOCTOR RE-EMERGES.
The TARDIS’ automated repairs will take a day or two. We just
have to wait.
So you can’t do a demonstration for us?
Not today, I’m afraid.
What a disappointment! — Come on, everyone. Back to work. No more gawping.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 19
FX: SERVANTS SHUFFLING BACK TO HALL. DOCTOR WALKS OVER TO NYSSA
& TEGAN.
Doctor? How long do you think we’1l be stuck here?
Not long. I made it look a bit more dramatic than it really is. I don’t want Mr Hurley demanding to see inside the TARDTS...
Good idea.
What I really wanted to do was find out when and where exactly we are in time.
And?
According to the instruments we’re in August eighteen-sixteen. Four miles south of the centre of Manchester. Something was niggling at me, you see... something I was trying to remember...
Hang on. The master of the house is coming over...
(ARRIVING) That was most diverting! The Doctor and his magic box! Perhaps later you could have a go at sawing your two ladies in half, eh? Hahaha!
Quite!
Hilarious.
Why would he want to saw us in half?
Listen, I’ve had a thought. Why don’t I give you a tour, Doctor? A man of learning like you. You’d be very interested!
Of your house?
House? It’s just a house. Nothing interesting about that. No, man. My pride and joy! My factory!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 20
Oh! Well, yes, that would be splendid.
It’s just a short ride into town...
This will be most interesting, I’m sure.
Yeah, riveting.
(QUIETLY, TO COMPANIONS) Nyssa, stay here, would you? The
will repair herself mostly, but she may require your help...
Of course, Doctor.
I wish we could just leave.
I’m very interested in this factory of his. Aren’t you, Tegan? This is your history, after all!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL)
9: INT. HURLEY’S FACTORY — FLOOR
Page 21
FX: VAST, THUNDERING NOISE OF MACHINES IN THE MILL. SPINNING,
POUNDING, THRESHING. GIGANTIC LOOMS AT WORK. NB: VOICES PITCHED SLIGHTLY UP OVER NOISE.
What do you have to say about this, then?
It’s certainly very impressive.
There’s nothing like it in the whole of the North West. Nay, in
the whole country, Doctor.
These machines... they’re huge!
Beautiful, aren’t they?
Monstrous, more like. How do people manage to work here and
stay sane?
Money in their pockets, in’t it? I support half the families in
south Manchester by providing them with work here.
It’s all quite an achievement.
So, you’re spinning yarn from cotton...
That’s right, Miss Jovanka.
Brought up the ship canal from Liverpool, and before that, from
America.
So it’s the slave trade.
Beg pardon?
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 22
Cotton picked by slaves in America, brought here to be spun by people on slave wages in Manchester...
Broadly true.
My people aren’t slaves!
You sure about that? Look at them. They look — [il1..] (REALISATION) Wait, those are children over there!
Yes. — Mr Hurley, I must say, the conditions here in your mill aren’t exactly the best. Rather worse than I’d hoped, [in fact]
FX: A CRACKING NOISE, AND SOME FEMALE SCREAMS.
(OFF) Watch out there!/Oh, look! Have a care...!
What’s that, sir? — Hang on... there’s something going off on the factory floor. Some fuss about nothing, as per usual.
(OFF) Someone help him!/Get him out of there!
There’s someone caught up in the workings!
(SHOUTING) What’s going on down there?
I can’t see from here. (CALLING) Someone stop the engines!
NO! The machines can’t stop!
Hurley, listen! There’s someone injured down there!
It’s a child!
Of course it is — only the kiddies are small enough to get underneath the machines, to pick up the waste and the chaff.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 23
He’s trapped. He’s been injured. Take my coat, Tegan.
What are you doing?
Keep away from there. There’s nothing to see.
I’m going underneath. I’m going to save him.
Doctor!!!
FX: FADE UP THUNDERING OF LOOMS.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 24
10: INT. HURLEY HALL — HALLWAY
FX: TICKING OF CLOCK. CATHY PASSES NYSSA.
(STOPPING NYSSA) Miss Nyssa, isn’t it?
That’s right.
I thought you’d gone into town with the others.
No, I was just going to check on the TARDIS—
Oh, your blue box, of course.
I saw you out in the garden last night, didn’t I?
That’s right, Miss. I was the first one out when your party... arrived.
It wasn’t a conventional materialisation. It must have come as something of a shock.
The words you lot use! I don’t understand some of them at all.
Oh!
Never mind, I mustn’t keep you. I should get on with tidying the drawing [room. ]
FX: DRAWING ROOM DOOR CREAKING OPEN, OFF.
(FROM OFF) Cathy!
Now I’m for it.
(WALKING FORWARD) Cathy, you mustn’t bother our guests. You have been warned before about talking to your betters.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 25
Yes.. Mrs Hurley.
(TO NYSSA) Good morning, my dear. I gather you are one of our impromptu visitors? I’m sorry I was too wretched to get up from my sick bed in the middle of the night in order to greet you...
Yes, I’m Nyssa. You must be Lady Hurley.
Oh, merely Mrs. I’m not a Lady. Not yet.
Mrs Hurley means that her husband hasn’t been knighted yet, for his services to industry, Nyssa.
Oh, I see! (SHE DOESN'T)
Cathy, you are impertinent.
Yes, Mrs Hurley.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 26
11: INT. FACTORY OFFICE. DAY.
FX: OFF — NOISY MACHINERY, QUIETER NOW. FUSS AND CHATTER FROM
WORKERS.
(CALLING, FROM DOORWAY) Back to your duties, all of you! There’s nothing to gawp at over there! — Here, Doctor, let them
clear up the mess!
FX: AS DOCTOR RETURNS:
Doctor?
(FX: CLOSING DOOR BEHIND HIM) The boy’s clear of the mechanism now. His lacerations seem superficial, but he’s very badly bruised.
Shouldn’t we get him to hospital?
Hospital, by hang! He doesn’t need an expensive hospital.
FX: DOOR CLASHES, WILLIAM DASHES IN.
I’ve just heard.. I was in the depot. What’s gone on?
Our Doctor friend here’s been a bit of a hero.
He saved that child’s life!
Which child?
He’s still down there on the factory floor. I must get back to him. I’1l need bandages, and, uh, surgical spirit?
FX: KNOCKING AT DOOR, TIMID.
William, answer that.
Yes, Father.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 27
FX: OFF — WILLIAM OPENING DOOR.
(OFF) We’ve come for ‘im./We mun’t take him home, to his people.
The boy’s alive, that’s the important thing. Maybe that’s the reason we came here, Doctor? So you could save him. For all we know, he’ll grow up to be someone important...
I shouldn’t think so, my dear. He’s just a factory hand. A raggy urchin.
(RETURNING) Father, the boy’s people are here. To take him home.

Let them have him! We don’t want any fuss. (TO WORKERS) Go on, then. I’ve had him looked at by an expert here — this Doctor! Take the boy home! Only get a shift on! I can’t have sickly kids lying about all over the place, taking up space. We’ve all got to get back to work! Chop chop!
FX: WORKERS HURRY AWAY.
I don’t believe this. — Mister Hurley!
Tegan, don’t aggravate my father. You’1ll make it worse...
Make what worse?
Hurley, the boy’s condition needs stabilising before he goes home. I’ve not yet cleaned his wounds properly.
Doctor, you’ve done more than enough.
(ACCUSINGLY) They’re not even people to you, are they?
What?!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 28
The Doctor’s trying to help that boy and all you’re concerned about is getting the machines going again!
Tegan, this isn’t helping.
I’1ll show you helping. I’m going after those people right now, to see that the boy gets home OK.
You can’t go off with that lot! Alone, I mean...
I don’t need a bodyguard.
You’re new to this city. I insist.
(SIGH) Come on, then.
FX: AS TEGAN AND WILLIAM EXIT:
I’1ll see you later, back at the Hall. (FX: DOOR CLASHES) Now,
Mr Hurley — we need to talk about this factory of yours.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 29
12. INT. HURLEY HALL — DRAWING ROOM
FX: NYSSA AND MRS HURLEY SIT.
Sit with me, Miss Nyssa.
Thank you.
(AT DOOR) May I go, Mrs Hurley?
Yes, yes, be off with you.
Very good, madam. (TURNS)
Wait! Before you go — tell me, how is that small brother of yours? How is Peter?
Oh, he’s thriving. An absolute devil. He’s so clever... and bonny.
You and your father are extremely lucky, my dear. To have new life around you. New possibilities. How wonderful to have a child to treasure like that...
Who is this baby she’s talking about, Cathy?
My brother, Miss. He’s our miracle baby.
Perhaps... one day you might bring him up to the Hall?
(SURPRISED) Yes, Mrs Hurley, if it can be arranged...
It’s been a long time since this place had any new life or laughter within its walls. I would be most grateful, Cathy.
I’1l talk to my dad. He’s not best pleased with me just now, though.
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 30
He is a good father. He has stuck by you.
He has forbidden me from going on tomorrow’s march.
This march! I wish they’d call it off.
NYSSA3: What kind of march is it to be?
It’s our chance. The working people. We’re all getting together and marching into Manchester. There’1ll be speeches and banners and music... It’ll be like one big jamboree!
I agree with your father. I don’t think you should go.
You forget, madam, what it’s like to be a working person and to feel like we do. You’ve been married so long to a rich man.
(OUTRAGED) Catherine Roberts!
It’s true, though - that you were one of us once, Mrs Hurley? You lived in the same village, did the same work. Ordinary, like the rest of us.
I don’t need lecturing by you — a servant girl!
I didn’t mean anything bad by it!
(AWKWARD) Perhaps I should go.
You stay where you are, Miss Nyssa! Being told where I belong... by you, Cathy! By a girl who’s no better than she ought to be! Get out, girl! Out of my Sight...!
I — yes, Mrs Hurley. (EXITS)
(CALLING AFTER) Don’t bother bringing that brat of yours here! Don’t you ever bother coming back here, for that matter!
THE PETERLOO MASSACRE by Paul Magrs (FINAL) Page 31
Please, Mrs Hurley, don’t be rash. I’m quite sure Cathy didn’t mean any offence.
Oh, so you presume to lecture me also?
No, that’s not it at all —
Then you can get out and all!
(GETTING UP) I’m very sorry, Mrs Hurley —
Go on, out! You don’t belong in my house either!
FX: NYSSA HURRIES OUT AFTER CATHY.
